items.title: Enough with the baby steps! Let‚Äôs make accessibility leaps. (My rejected axe-con submission.)
items.content_html:
This was my submission for axe-con 2024 which unfortunately did not make it to the conference. Let me know if the topic would be interesting for you and you would like to hear more about the topic!

  • Title: Enough with the baby steps! Let‚Äôs make accessibility leaps.

  • Outline: So much of our work is based on nudging people into the right direction. Applying a little pressure that makes a change but is not disruptive. This needs to change. This talk showcases steps that we can take that make instant notable differences for disabled people using websites and apps by using policy changes that are strong and disruptive once, instead of continuous glacially slow progress.

  • Additional Information: I don‚Äôt expect this to be the most technical talk, but it might be most suitable for people who lead teams or companies, hence I selected intermediate. The talk‚Äôs goal is to shake people awake and show how gradually improving accessibility is often not the best way to spend their effort.

(Slightly edited for grammar.)

- **Outline:** So much of our work is based on nudging people into the right direction. Applying a little pressure that makes a change but is not disruptive. This needs to change. This talk showcases steps that we can take that make instant notable differences for disabled people using websites and apps by using policy changes that are strong and disruptive once, instead of continuous glacially slow progress.

- **Additional Information:** I don‚Äôt expect this to be the most technical talk, but it might be most suitable for people who lead teams or companies, hence I selected intermediate. The talk‚Äôs goal is to shake people awake and show how gradually improving accessibility is often not the best way to spend their effort.

(Slightly edited for grammar.)

items.title: Accessibility in the real world
items.content_html:
This is a repost of a Twitter thread from August 2022. Slightly edited in format and for clarity.

Accessibility must work within the constraints of an ableist world to improve things. I hope it can help to make the world a tiny bit less unjust every day.

I have seen accessibility people say ‚Äúthis is a hill I‚Äôm willing to die on‚Äù and then they died on that proverbial hill.

Some clients just don‚Äôt care, and you have no power to make them care. You can make them aware, you can put procedures in place, you can point at laws. But you can‚Äôt change their attitude.

And yes, that might mean that the products of the process are‚Ä¶ mediocre at best.

That is disappointing for the accessibility professionals involved, who did their best in the circumstances, and still fail many disabled people.

I think it‚Äôs still important to do this work:

Awareness is important, and when more people are aware that accessibility is a thing, more people will be willing to invest in it. This is a slow process, but I have seen it in real life: Companies that have an audit done for compliance and then want to get better.

And sometimes you inspire people to get into accessibility and they might be having an impact for a long time.

Is any of this optimal? No.

Do I wish I had a magic wand that made disability justice a reality and everyone care? You bet!

But I don‚Äôt, and so I need to have my practice grounded in the reality of the world as it is, as it otherwise becomes burnout inducing.

And if we cannot afford one thing, that‚Äôs people quitting accessibility because they are burned out. Because they feel that they are ineffective and their work is worthless. I feel like that all the time.

That said, the WebAIM Million study shows that between 2019 and 2022 the average error per page has decreased and the most common issues have also decreased. The web is slowly getting better.

I strongly believe that we must change the systems to make web accessibility easier, especially aligning what‚Äôs right with what‚Äôs easy. Currently a lot of accessibility practices on the web are hidden or require additional knowledge. That is an ableist barrier itself.

I wrote about changing the system on my blog.

I also recorded a talk about the topic.

I have seen accessibility people say ‚Äúthis is a hill I‚Äôm willing to die on‚Äù and then they died on that proverbial hill.

Some clients just don‚Äôt care, and you have no power to make them care. You can make them aware, you can put procedures in place, you can point at laws. But you can‚Äôt change their attitude.

And yes, that might mean that the products of the process are‚Ä¶ mediocre at best.

That is disappointing for the accessibility professionals involved, who did their best in the circumstances, and still fail many disabled people. 

I think it‚Äôs still important to do this work:

Awareness is important, and when more people are aware that accessibility is a thing, more people will be willing to invest in it. This is a slow process, but I have seen it in real life: Companies that have an audit done for compliance and then want to get better.

And sometimes you inspire people to get into accessibility and they might be having an impact for a long time.

Is any of this optimal? No. 

Do I wish I had a magic wand that made disability justice a reality and everyone care? You bet!

But I don‚Äôt, and so I need to have my practice grounded in the reality of the world as it is, as it otherwise becomes burnout inducing.

**And if we cannot afford one thing, that‚Äôs people quitting accessibility because they are burned out. Because they feel that they are ineffective and their work is worthless.
I feel like that all the time.**

I wrote about [changing the system on my blog](https://yatil.net/blog/fix-web-accessibility-systematically).

items.title: Quick guidance for referring to (parts of) HTML elements
items.content_html:
You always need to be very clear in what you mean. Otherwise, it is hard to read for your audience. Always include brackets with the element names. You can differentiate attributes and values by using these words. Always include the word ‚Äúvalue‚Äù when talking about values.

  • First mention of an element: ‚Äú<h1> element‚Äù
  • First mention of an attribute: ‚Äúid attribute‚Äù
  • First mention of a value: ‚Äúmy-great-id value‚Äù
  • Subsequent mention of an element: ‚Äú<h1>‚Äù or ‚Äú<h1> element‚Äù
  • Subsequent mention of an attribute: ‚Äúid‚Äù or ‚Äúid attribute‚Äù
  • Subsequent mention of a value: ‚Äúmy-great-id value‚Äù
  • Avoid the use of ‚Äútag‚Äù when the whole element is the subject of the sentence, do only use ‚Äútag‚Äù when it is specific to the start or end tag. Always specify ‚Äústart tag‚Äù or ‚Äúend tag‚Äù.
items.content_text:
You always need to be very clear in what you mean. Otherwise, it is hard to read for your audience. Always include brackets with the element names. You can differentiate attributes and values by using these words. Always include the word ‚Äúvalue‚Äù when talking about values.

- First mention of an element: ‚Äú`<h1>` element‚Äù
- First mention of an attribute: ‚Äú`id` attribute‚Äù
- First mention of a value: ‚Äú`my-great-id` value‚Äù
- Subsequent mention of an element:  ‚Äú`<h1>`‚Äù or ‚Äú`<h1>` element‚Äù
- Subsequent mention of an attribute: ‚Äú`id`‚Äù or ‚Äú`id` attribute‚Äù
- Subsequent mention of a value: ‚Äú`my-great-id` value‚Äù
- Avoid the use of ‚Äútag‚Äù when the whole element is the subject of the sentence, do only use ‚Äútag‚Äù when it is specific to the start or end tag. Always specify ‚Äústart tag‚Äù or ‚Äúend tag‚Äù.

Publishing your accessibility resources as PDFs actively excludes people.

‚ÄúAccessible PDFs‚Äù are not really a thing. Tagged PDFs benefit mostly screen reader users, which is better than not having it, but it is a far cry from the accessibility and flexibility HTML web pages can give users.

items.content_html: Why does the ARIA Practices Guide have such bad guidance? Never use menubars unless it is a menu like in a desktop application: File/Edit/View, that kind of stuff. (APG shows what can be done with ARIA, but does not care if it makes sense in practice.)
items.content_text: Why does the ARIA Practices Guide have [such bad guidance]( https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/example-index/menubar/menubar-navigation)? **Never** use `menubar`s unless it is a menu like in a desktop application: File/Edit/View, that kind of stuff. (APG shows what can be done with ARIA, but does not care if it makes sense in practice.)

items.title: Silicon Valley conspiracy theories might just be capitalism
items.content_html:
Theories abound that Silicon Valley executives got together to slash jobs. Or that a cabal of hedge funds conspired and forced them to do it.

While I have literally no insight into these companies, I think the reason is ‚Äúthe market‚Äù of capitalism. These companies are very similar in how they operate and how they are structured. And they are all “public” companies, meaning that their share price is one of the most important measures of success.

As the cost of doing business rises due to inflation, the share price is under threat. And because it used to be good for the share price to stockpile new employees ‚Äì even for the simple reason of keeping that talent out of the hands of your competitors ‚Äì it is no longer seen as appropriate. So companies are doing what they need to do to stabilise the share price and avoid bad press.

One company in particular that has not announced layoffs is Apple, where Tim Cook took a 40% pay cut. He didn’t do it out of the goodness of his heart either, but because his ‚Äúballooning compensation‚Äù was becoming a problem with shareholders. I am sure Apple will try not to do what all its competitors are doing, because it has often worked to their advantage, and Cook’s pay cut can act as a shield against some bad press. Sometimes you gotta zig when everybody else is zagging.

What it shows is that employees, especially in large, monopolistic companies, are used as pawns to keep investors happy. Tenure and success don’t matter if you can be made redundant to make the figures look good.

You don’t need people conspiring to do this, you just need a system that rewards this behaviour.

items.title: Illustrations with flexbox
items.content_html:
Data-informed flex-grow for illustration purposes

This week, I added a bit of page count-based visualisation for fun.

This is what it looks like: rectangles with colours based on book covers. Each relates to a specific book, and its size is based on that book’s page count.

Hidde uses clever CSS techniques to create visualizations. I love it!

items.content_html:
Expertise is not to know everything.

It is to know what is important. It is to know where to look up details. It is to mediate between concurrent needs. It‚Äôs to explain and filter the relevant information to others. It‚Äôs (especially!) knowing where its limits are.

Expertise is **not** to know everything.

It is to know what is important. It is to know where to look up details. It is to mediate between concurrent needs. It‚Äôs to explain and filter the relevant information to others. It‚Äôs (especially!) knowing where its limits are.

items.title: W3C membership & inflation
items.content_html:
It‚Äôs very interesting that a full W3C membership cost $50k/year in 1995 while it currently costs a maximum of 77K. Adjusted for inflation, the fee should be 93K.

Of course there are many more members these days, but 77K for a billion+ company feels like a drop in the bucket‚Ä¶
items.content_text:
It‚Äôs very interesting that [a full W3C membership cost $50k/year in 1995](https://w3c.social/@plehegar/109593223455061643) while it currently costs [a maximum of 77K](https://www.w3.org/Consortium/fees?countryCode=US&quarter=01-01&year=2023#results). [Adjusted for inflation](https://westegg.com/inflation/infl.cgi?money=50000&first=1995&final=2021), the fee should be 93K.

Of course there are many more members these days, but 77K for a billion+ company feels like a drop in the bucket‚Ä¶

items.title: W3C Accessibility Maturity Model
items.content_html:
I did not manage to read this yet, but there is this W3C Accessibility Maturity Model document at W3C:

The W3C Accessibility Maturity Model is a guide for organizations to evaluate and improve their business processes to produce digital products that are accessible to people with disabilities. Use of the W3C Accessibility Maturity Model will provide organizations informative guidance (guidance that is not normative and does not set requirements) on improving accessibility policies, processes, and outcomes.

‚ö†Ô∏è Despite being in the same folder URL as a Web Standard, and looking like a Web Standard, this is only a Working Group Note and hence has not necessary gotten W3C consensus.
items.content_text:
I did not manage to read this yet, but there is this [W3C Accessibility Maturity Model](https://www.w3.org/TR/maturity-model/#description-dimensions) document at W3C: 

> The W3C Accessibility Maturity Model is a guide for organizations to evaluate and improve their business processes to produce digital products that are accessible to people with disabilities. Use of the W3C Accessibility Maturity Model will provide organizations informative guidance (guidance that is not normative and does not set requirements) on improving accessibility policies, processes, and outcomes.

‚ö†Ô∏è Despite being in the same folder URL as a Web Standard, and looking like a Web Standard, this is only a Working Group Note and hence has not necessary gotten W3C consensus.

items.title: Mapping 4.1.1 to other Success Criteria
items.content_html:
The 411 on 4.1.1 ‚Äî Adrian Roselli

There is a non-zero chance that WCAG Success Criterion 4.1.1 Parsing will go away in WCAG 2.2. This isn‚Äôt a problem for users, regardless of the problems it may pose for the WCAG process, ACT rules, automated testing tools, or ossified testing processes.

Very insightful and measured approach by Adrian that IMHO clearly shows why 4.1.1 can go away without any serious changes to how we test.
items.content_text:
**[The 411 on 4.1.1 ‚Äî Adrian Roselli](https://adrianroselli.com/2022/12/the-411-on-4-1-1.html)**

Very insightful and measured approach by Adrian that IMHO clearly shows why 4.1.1 can go away without any serious changes to how we test.

items.title: Take worries and fears seriously, seriously
items.content_html:
A few people wear yellow vests and complain about high fossil fuel prices. We have to take the worries and fears of people seriously.

People protest against the protection of vulnerable people during a global pandemic. We have to take the worries and fears of people seriously.

Some individualy stoke hate and fear against minoritized groups. We have to take the worries and fears of people seriously.

The youth across the world protests several years to force action against a climate crisis that will threaten their future. ü¶ó

Some of these activists disturb traffic. We lock them up for a month.

Some of these activists disturb an airport. This needs to have serious consequences.

Why is nobody taking the worries and fears that young people have regarding climate change seriously? Why do right-wing, climate-denying, anti-vaxx groups have worries and fears that need to be taken seriously? Doesn‚Äôt it make sense that a whole generation feels abandoned and not taken seriously? Are we supposed to be surprised if they are getting desparate? This is the question that I want politicians to ask themselves. And then make it right.

items.content_html:
The Everything Bagel

@jean on what makes micro.blog special (emphasis mine):

Like the Everything Bagel, we think we know what should be included. We assume certain features are important. When I started working with Manton Reece on Micro.blog, I was the one peppering him with questions, such is how do I retweet, why no hashtags, where can I find out who is following me and how many followers I have. I thought Micro.blog should be Twitter minus the trolls. I had no way to imagine another way of doing things. Where are my poppy seeds?

Today, over five years later, I treasure what we have built at Micro.blog. It is what Manton envisioned: a thoughtful space for people to write and share and converse. I love it the way it is. The community and the experience has evolved in its own way, thanks to the contributions and participation of lots of individual humans.

items.content_html:
Shaming people who leave a toxic place because the new place is not 100% non-toxic is a weird flex that happens on Twitter right now.

Sure Twitter alternatives are not the most accessible, but neither was Twitter when you joined it (unless you joined in the last 12 months or so). Pretending Twitter didn‚Äôt become accessible because people joined it in the inaccessible state and lobbied hard for it to become better is not recognizing Twitter‚Äôs history in this area.

Yes, Mastodon is not super accessible, and there are barriers. But there are good and well-documented workarounds (like there were on Twitter back in the day!) which we can build upon. Because nothing is won when Twitter is defunct and there is no alternative. We have to start now.

items.title: Twitter was never forever
items.content_html:
I really don‚Äôt want to talk about Twitter‚Äôs demise, but part of my grieving process seems to be to think about it. So, sorry.

It‚Äôs not surprising but still shocking to see that most people do not have any contingency at all for losing their primary social network. If Friendster, Pownce, App.net, GeoCities, Myspace, and Ping have taught us anything then that even big networks do fail (and Ping). Some crumble gradually and lose their usefulness. Others explode into fiery supernovas and burn out.

People active in the indie web community have always warned from putting all content into one social network that you do not have control over. But that is exactly what many people have done with Twitter. And I get it. Not everyone can and wants to have their own website. We see the same thing happen with sites like Linktree. But if your ‚Äì for the lack of better words ‚Äì content creation relies on a singular platform you have no control over, you should expect it to go away at any moment, and plan accordingly.

That is why I am encouraging people to test out alternatives, even if there are obstacles and (accessibility) barriers. Because learning work-arounds and favorite ways to interact on different platforms now is much easier than doing it later. You don‚Äôt have to switch 100% or burn your Twitter account, nobody expects that. Experiment with an account on Mastodon or micro.blog or Myspace (turns out it‚Äôs not 100% dead yet).

I still reply and interact with people on Twitter and there is a good chance you came to this post from there. That‚Äôs totally fine. Use what is comfortable for you, but also be aware of your options.
items.content_text:
_I really don‚Äôt want to talk about Twitter‚Äôs demise, but part of my grieving process seems to be to think about it. So, sorry._

It‚Äôs not surprising but still shocking to see that most people do not have any contingency at all for losing their primary social network. If [Friendster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendster), [Pownce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pownce), [App.net](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/App.net), [GeoCities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yahoo!_GeoCities), [Myspace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myspace), and [Ping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITunes_Ping) have taught us anything then that even big networks do fail (and Ping). Some crumble gradually and lose their usefulness. Others explode into fiery supernovas and burn out.

People active in the [indie web](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IndieWeb) community have always warned from putting all content into one social network that you do not have control over. But that is exactly what many people have done with Twitter. And I get it. Not everyone can and wants to have their own website. We see the same thing happen with sites like Linktree. But if your ‚Äì for the lack of better words ‚Äì content creation relies on a singular platform you have no control over, you should expect it to go away at any moment, and plan accordingly.

That is why I am encouraging people to test out alternatives, even if there are obstacles and (accessibility) barriers. Because learning work-arounds and favorite ways to interact on different platforms _now_ is much easier than doing it later. You don‚Äôt have to switch 100% or burn your Twitter account, nobody expects that. Experiment with an account on Mastodon or micro.blog or Myspace (turns out it‚Äôs not 100% dead yet).

I still reply and interact with people on Twitter and there is a good chance you came to this post from there. That‚Äôs totally fine. Use what is comfortable for you, but also be aware of your options.

items.content_html: Lots of people refer to different Mastodon instances as ‚Äúsilos‚Äù in contrast to Twitter where there are ‚Äúno silos‚Äù. The reality is the opposite because all instances talk to each other. Twitter is the mall where you get a place but it sets the rules and doesn‚Äôt let you talk to other shops in other malls. The fediverse is high street with individual shops that talk to each other.

items.title: My bike and its inner tube (follow-up) üö¥
items.content_html:
Today I think I repaired my front bike inner tube properly. I got a bike holder to put my bike on while working on it, and after I set it up, I thought I could take another look at the inner tube. Turns out the patch got lose again, probably during reassembly or while adding air.

I also found out that the tube that I got from the shop is only a 24/28-622 size tube, which is very small for a 45-622 wheel. So I probably inflated it too much to fill the wheel, making a defect more likely.

I will see if it holds the air over night but I‚Äôll probably switch out the inner tube to the right size one once I get it tomorrow. This is fun to figure out, even if a bit frustrating. But better at home in the garage than on the track.

items.content_html:
Finished reading: The Patrios Network by Antony Johnston üìö

In his latest book, Antony not only works through the Covid pandemic and the rise of right-wing militaristic groups, but also weaves together an intriguing tech-spy story. Brigitte Sharp is (as always) a brilliant protagonist, but the book also paints a more well rounded picture of her place in SIS and the world. Tension is always high and there is rarely a time to breath.

I loved it.

items.title: Finding people you follow on Twitter in the Fediverse
items.content_html: Use this handy tool by @Luca@vis.social to find users in the Fediverse that you follow on Twitter:
items.content_text:
Use this handy tool by [@Luca@vis.social](https://micro.blog/Luca@vis.social) to find users in the Fediverse that you follow on Twitter:

I wrote a nano tool that tries to extract the #Fediverse accounts of your #Twitter followings: https://fedifinder.glitch.me/

It searches for the patterns @user@host.tld, user@host.tld and host.tld/@user in the screen name, description, location and URL field. It displays them to you in the correct format for easy copying as well as a CSV download that can be imported to #Mastodon.

Known issue: Mail addresses are included as false positives because people write their handle without a leading @: name@host.tld

Luca Hammer https://vis.social/@Luca/109253908218072543

items.title: Fake tweet generator
items.content_html:
I love how none of these ‚ÄúAI generated‚Äù tweets sound like anything I would tweet:

If 75% of your product’s revenue comes from 25% of your customers, what do you do about that?

(helping an e-commerce founder figure out their revenue model)

What (if any) are your favorite B2B products?

How many engineers does it take to build a successful product?

What’s the best product roadmap framework you’ve come across?

‚ö°Ô∏è (1) If you’re working on something you’re passionate about, there’s no better feeling than getting an email from someone you admire saying: Hey, I dug your podcast, keep up the great work!

‚ö°Ô∏è (2) If you’re working on something you’re passionate about, and someone you admire tells you they like what you’re doing, that’s even better.

If you’re building a product, and you know it solves a market need, what metrics do you use to measure success?

What’s the one thing you’ve done recently that made you feel good about your business?

The best ideas come from people not at the top of their field. The people are the leaders. The leaders are the followers.

‚ÄîJP Morgan Chase

A lot of people ask me this question, and I usually respond with:

I don’t know. Ask the founders.

But, I’m sharing what I’ve learned from talking to some founders who have done it.

Apparently I‚Äôm a VC person or business influencer‚Ä¶

items.title: Icons (and graphics) on an Inkplate 6COLOR
items.content_html:
One of the more complicated things was how to show icons on the Inkplate 6COLOR. Now, generally it is pretty easy: You take the graphic, you convert it into a C header file, import it and then render it to the screen.

However, there are a few challenges: The drawBitmap3Bit function that is used cannot scale the icon, which is a bit weird because it takes the size of the icon as parameters. But scaling is just not something that this function does.

It‚Äôs best is to export an icon immediately in the format and size you want to use. I exported from Sketch and that worked fine.

For icons that have the background full colored in one of the seven colors, make sure to make the color as close to the pure Inkplate color as possible:

Color Constant Value Hex
Black INKPLATE_BLACK 0 #000000
White INKPLATE_WHITE 1 #FFFFFF
Green INKPLATE_GREEN 2 #00FF00
Blue INKPLATE_BLUE 3 #0000FF
Red INKPLATE_RED 4 #FF0000
Yellow INKPLATE_YELLOW 5 #FFFF00
Orange INKPLATE_ORANGE 6 #FF8800

I tried out using half-transparent colors, but when I enabled dithering, it did also dither areas that had a solid color. I think going monochrome is best for icons, or you have to manually dither beforehand.

Then, use the [image converter] and upload the image. Select the correct Inkplate board and you should be good to go. Enter the pixel size of your image to get the best representation and click ‚ÄúConvert‚Äù. The code is output below the buttons and I almost overlooked it. It also has a preview of the file. Download the ‚ÄúHeader File‚Äù and place it next to your Arduino sketch file.

You can then import the file using

where iconname is your icon‚Äôs filename and also means that three variables are defined which you can immediately use in the aforementioned drawBitmap3Bit function:

  • iconname ‚Üí the graphic information
  • iconname_w ‚Üí width
  • iconname_w ‚Üí height

The following code would output a brain graphic in the middle of the screen:
items.content_text:
One of the more complicated things was how to show icons on the Inkplate 6COLOR. Now, generally it is pretty easy: You take the graphic, you convert it into a C header file, import it and then render it to the screen. However, there are a few challenges: The [`drawBitmap3Bit`](https://inkplate.readthedocs.io/en/latest/arduino.html#inkplate-drawbitmap3bit) function that is used cannot scale the icon, which is a bit weird because it takes the size of the icon as parameters. But scaling is just not something that this function does. It‚Äôs best is to export an icon immediately in the format and size you want to use. I exported from Sketch and that worked fine. For icons that have the background full colored in one of the seven colors, make sure to make the color as close to the pure Inkplate color as possible: | Color | Constant | Value | Hex | ------ | --------------- | :---: | :-----: | Black | INKPLATE_BLACK | 0 | #000000 | White | INKPLATE_WHITE | 1 | #FFFFFF | Green | INKPLATE_GREEN | 2 | #00FF00 | Blue | INKPLATE_BLUE | 3 | #0000FF | Red | INKPLATE_RED | 4 | #FF0000 | Yellow | INKPLATE_YELLOW | 5 | #FFFF00 | Orange | INKPLATE_ORANGE | 6 | #FF8800 I tried out using half-transparent colors, but when I enabled dithering, it did also dither areas that had a solid color. I think going monochrome is best for icons, or you have to manually dither beforehand. Then, use the [image converter] and upload the image. Select the correct Inkplate board and you should be good to go. Enter the pixel size of your image to get the best representation and click ‚ÄúConvert‚Äù. The code is output below the buttons and I almost overlooked it. It also has a preview of the file. Download the ‚ÄúHeader File‚Äù and place it next to your Arduino sketch file. You can then import the file using 
#include "iconname.h"
where `iconname` is your icon‚Äôs filename and also means that three variables are defined which you can immediately use in the aforementioned [`drawBitmap3Bit`](https://inkplate.readthedocs.io/en/latest/arduino.html#inkplate-drawbitmap3bit) function: * iconname ‚Üí the graphic information * iconname_w ‚Üí width * iconname_w ‚Üí height The following code would output a brain graphic in the middle of the screen: 
#include "brain.h"

display.drawBitmap3Bit(display.width() / 2 - (brain_w / 2), display.height() / 2 - (brain_h / 2), brain, brain_w, brain_h);

items.title: Inkplate 6COLOR on macOS
items.content_html:
How I got my Inkplate 6COLOR running on macOS:

  1. Install Python 3. (I already had that, you can check the command line which python 3 and if there is a result, you are good to go.)
  2. Install the CH340 driver. This driver basically is responsible for having macOS ‚Äúsee the device‚Äù through USB.
  3. Install the legacy Arduino IDE (version 1.8.x). Did I try the 2.0 version? Yes! Did it completely break wifi and networking until a restart? Also yes! The legacy version works flawlessly.
  4. Open Arduino IDE and go to settings. Paste the following URL into the ‚ÄùAdditional Boards Manager URL‚Äù field: https://github.com/e-radionicacom/Dasduino-Board-Definitions-for-Arduino-IDE/raw/master/package_Dasduino_Boards_index.json. This makes the instructions and libraries available to Arduino.
  5. Go to Tools ‚Üí Board: ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Üí Boards Manager‚Ä¶ ‚Üí Search for Inkplate ‚Üí Install
  6. After installation is complete, run the following command on your command line: sed -i -e 's/=python /=python3 /g' ~/Library/Arduino15/packages/Inkplate_Boards/hardware/esp32/*/platform.txt. This basically replaces all calls to python with calls to the previously installed python3.
  7. Connect the display and press the button next to the USB-C port. Select the port of the display from the Tools ‚Üí Port menu in Arduino IDE. Here it looks like /dev/cu.wchusbserial14310 ‚Äì Note that the number behind the name can change when you change ports.
  8. Download the example files.
  9. Open an example in Arduino IDE 1.8 by selecting the .ino file in a folder. Press the checkmark to verify the code, and the right pointing arrow to deploy it to your display.
  10. Some examples might need additional Libraries, like the super useful ArduinoJson one. To install such a library go to Tools ‚Üí Manage Libraries‚Ä¶ ‚Üí Search for the library you need and press install.
  11. Read the Manual. While I struggled to set it up so m computer was able to communicate and deploy Arduino programs to the display, once it was set up the different drawing and text output methods are pretty straight forward to understand. That said, it helps if you have seen C++ code in your life before as some descriptions use notations that are easier to understand that way.
items.content_text:
How I got my [Inkplate 6COLOR](https://www.crowdsupply.com/soldered/inkplate-6color) running on macOS:

1. Install Python 3. (I already had that, you can check the command line `which python 3` and if there is a result, you are good to go.)
2. Install [the CH340 driver](https://github.com/adrianmihalko/ch340g-ch34g-ch34x-mac-os-x-driver). This driver basically is responsible for having macOS ‚Äúsee the device‚Äù through USB.
3. Install the [**legacy** Arduino IDE (version 1.8.x)](https://www.arduino.cc/en/software#legacy-ide-18x). Did I try the 2.0 version? Yes! Did it completely break wifi and networking until a restart? Also yes! The legacy version works flawlessly.
4. Open Arduino IDE and go to settings. Paste the following URL into the ‚ÄùAdditional Boards Manager URL‚Äù field: `https://github.com/e-radionicacom/Dasduino-Board-Definitions-for-Arduino-IDE/raw/master/package_Dasduino_Boards_index.json`. This makes the instructions and libraries available to Arduino.
5. Go to Tools ‚Üí Board: ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Üí Boards Manager‚Ä¶ ‚Üí Search for Inkplate ‚Üí Install
6. After installation is complete, run the following command on your command line: `sed -i -e 's/=python /=python3 /g' ~/Library/Arduino15/packages/Inkplate_Boards/hardware/esp32/*/platform.txt`. This basically replaces all calls to `python` with calls to the previously installed `python3`.
7. Connect the display and press the button next to the USB-C port. Select the port of the display from the Tools ‚Üí Port menu in Arduino IDE. Here it looks like `/dev/cu.wchusbserial14310` ‚Äì Note that the number behind the name can change when you change ports.
8. Download the [example files](https://github.com/e-radionicacom/Inkplate-Arduino-library/tree/master/examples/Inkplate6COLOR).
9. Open an example in Arduino IDE 1.8 by selecting the `.ino` file in a folder. Press the checkmark to verify the code, and the right pointing arrow to deploy it to your display.
10. Some examples might need additional Libraries, like the super useful [ArduinoJson](https://arduinojson.org) one. To install such a library go to Tools ‚Üí Manage Libraries‚Ä¶ ‚Üí Search for the library you need and press install.
11. **[Read the Manual.](https://inkplate.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html)** While I struggled to set it up so m computer was able to communicate and deploy Arduino programs to the display, once it was set up the different drawing and text output methods are pretty straight forward to understand. That said, it helps if you have seen C++ code in your life before as some descriptions use notations that are easier to understand that way.

items.content_html:
‚ÄòIt Felt Like a Funeral‚Äô ‚Äî William Shatner on his feelings when he was on that Blue OrIgin space flight:

[‚Ä¶B]eauty isn‚Äôt out there, it‚Äôs down here, with all of us. Leaving that behind made my connection to our tiny planet even more profound.

It was among the strongest feelings of grief I have ever encountered. The contrast between the vicious coldness of space and the warm nurturing of Earth below filled me with overwhelming sadness.

items.title: Snooker Hong Kong Masters 2022
items.content_html:
Awesome Hong Kong Masters final between Ronnie O‚ÄôSullivan and Marco Fu.

Ronnie getting into a commanding lead before the mid-session interval and then struggleing a little to get over the line. No super-high breaks, but Ronnie‚Äôs 114 clearance basically without black and pink in the final frame was excellent.

And Marco punched over his weight, too. A close contest was expected after the 147 Maximum in the semi final. And Marco didn‚Äôt disappoint. After a tense start, he found his cool and got better into the match.

Add 8000+ spectators, a record for Snooker in, and it was a really formidable contest. Plus: excellent mask wearing! So civil!

üé± üî¥

items.title: Handling a winter storm
items.content_html:
Some words of advice I just shared to my colleagues in Austin who have a winter storm they don‚Äôt have the infrastructure to deal with, including power outages.

  • Please stay safe.
  • Stay inside.
  • Turn your phones off in case you need it in an emergency and there is no power.
  • Get lots of blankets and multiple layers of clothes.
  • Especially protect extremities and wear a warm cap. Put it over your ears.
  • Put tea/coffee in thermos and drink it slowly over multiple hours, that gives you some warmth over the day.
  • If you have large glass windows or doors, put blankets over them. The air trapped between the window and the blanket is isolating.
  • If you run a gas stove, open the window (a little bit) when using it.

Oh, and don‚Äôt expect to be productive or clear thinking when it is very cold. Your body needs the energy to keep warm. That‚Äôs normal.
items.content_text:
Some words of advice I just shared to my colleagues in Austin who have a winter storm they don‚Äôt have the infrastructure to deal with, including power outages. 

* Please stay safe.
* Stay inside.
* Turn your phones off in case you need it in an emergency and there is no power. 
* Get lots of blankets and multiple layers of clothes. 
* Especially protect extremities and wear a warm cap. Put it over your ears.
* Put tea/coffee in thermos and drink it slowly over multiple hours, that gives you some warmth over the day.
* If you have large glass windows or doors, put blankets over them. The air trapped between the window and the blanket is isolating.
* If you run a gas stove, open the window (a little bit) when using it.

Oh, and don‚Äôt expect to be productive or clear thinking when it is very cold. Your body needs the energy to keep warm. That‚Äôs normal.

items.content_html:
Okay, #a11y peeps. Is it really a problem to have an <aside> inside of the <main> element? I have seen that assessment a couple of times, and I question if that‚Äôs correct.

The ARIA Spec says about role="complementary", which <aside> has:

A supporting section of the document, designed to be complementary to the main content at a similar level in the DOM hierarchy, but remains meaningful when separated from the main content.

Similar level feels like it permits nesting. Does it create any tangible downsides in practice?

ü¶æ
items.content_text:
Okay, #a11y peeps. Is it really a problem to have an `<aside>` inside of the `<main>` element? I have seen that assessment a couple of times, and I question if that‚Äôs correct.

The [ARIA Spec says about `role="complementary"`, which `<aside>` has](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/#complementary):

> A supporting section of the document, designed to be complementary to the main content at a similar level in the DOM hierarchy, but remains meaningful when separated from the main content.

Similar level _feels_ like it permits nesting. Does it create any tangible downsides in practice? 

ü¶æ

items.content_html:
PSA:

In W3C a Note is recommending something. For example the ARIA Practices document is a note and it‚Äôs recommended to do what is in there.

A Recommendation is a standard and you must write your website according to those standards.

Not confusing at all! üòÇ
items.content_text:
PSA:

In W3C a _Note_ is recommending something. For example the ARIA Practices document is a note and it‚Äôs recommended to do what is in there.

A _Recommendation_ is a standard and you _must_ write your website according to those standards.

Not confusing at all! üòÇ
